raw_text:
Steady job growth continues in US
 
 The US created fewer jobs than expected in December, but analysts said that the dip in hiring was not enough to derail the world's biggest economy.
 
 According to Labor Department figures, 157,000 new jobs were added last month. That took 2004's total to 2.2 million, the best showing in five years. Job creation was one of last year's main concerns for the US economy. While worries still remain, the conditions are set for steady growth in 2005, analysts said. The unemployment rate stayed at 5.4% in December, and about 200,000 jobs will need to be created each month if that figure is to drop.
 
 "It was a respectable report," said Michael Moran, analyst at Daiwa Securities.
 
 "Payroll growth in December was a little lighter than the consensus forecast, but we had upward revisions to the prior two months and an increase in manufacturing employment." "Manufacturing is a cyclical area of the economy and if it's showing job growth, it's a good indication that the economy is on a solid growth track." That means that the Federal Reserve is likely to continue its policy of raising interest rates. The Fed lifted borrowing costs five times last year to 2.25%, citing evidence the US economic recovery was becoming more robust.
 
 Job creation was one of last year's main concerns for the US economy, and proved to be a main topic of debate in the US presidential election. While demand for workers is far from booming, the conditions are set for steady growth. "Overall, compared to the previous year it looks great, it just keeps going stronger and stronger and I expect that to be the case" in 2005, said Kurt Karl, economist at Swiss Re in New York. Meanwhile, economists cautioned against reading too much into data from the Federal Reserve showing an unexpected $8.7bn drop in consumer debt in November. A fall in consumer spending, which makes up about two-thirds of all US economic activity, could help limit the extent of any future interest rate rises. But economists said there could be a number of reasons for a fall in the borrowing, which include credit cards and personal loans, while noting that such figures can vary on a month-to-month basis.
llama3.2:1b: US job growth continued at 157,000 new jobs added in December, exceeding expectations by a small margin. This brings the US total to 2.2 million, the best showing since 2004. The unemployment rate remained at 5.4%, with about 200,000 additional jobs needed each month for the figure to drop. Analysts view this as a sign that steady growth is on track. The Fed may raise interest rates again due to robust economic recovery evidence.
llama3.2:3b: US created 157,000 new jobs in December, boosting total to 2.2 million, but leaving unemployment rate at 5.4%. Analysts say conditions are set for steady growth in 2005 despite ongoing job creation concerns. Federal Reserve is likely to continue raising interest rates. Consumer debt fell unexpectedly in November, potentially limiting future rate hikes.
gemma2:2b: US job growth slowed slightly in December but remains steady overall. 157,000 jobs were added, exceeding previous months' revisions and increasing total jobs for the year to 2.2 million. The unemployment rate stayed at 5.4%, requiring continued job creation to decrease it.  The Federal Reserve is likely to continue raising interest rates due to this positive trend. Economists believe US economic growth will continue in 2005, despite concerns about consumer spending and potential reasons for the sudden drop in consumer debt.
qwen2.5:0.5b: US job growth is expected to remain steady despite fewer jobs being created than initially anticipated. Analysts expect the unemployment rate to stay at 5.4%, with about 200, 000 new jobs needed each month if that number drops. The Federal Reserve is likely to continue raising interest rates to combat inflation.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Job growth was slightly lower than expected in December, but remained strong overall. The unemployment rate stayed steady at 5.4%, with about 200,000 jobs needed each month to reduce the figure. Analysts expect steady economic growth in 2005 due to cyclical job creation in manufacturing and continued interest rate increases by the Federal Reserve. Despite concerns over rising consumer debt, economists caution against predicting future economic downturns based on temporary figures like those from November's drop in consumer spending.
qwen2.5:3b: Steady job growth continues in US despite fewer than expected jobs added in December. Total 2004 employment reached 2.2 million, with unemployment at 5.4%. Analysts predict steady growth for 2005 due to manufacturing showing positive job growth and continued interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve. Job concerns were significant last year but conditions are favorable now. While consumer debt dropped unexpectedly in November, economists suggest this does not necessarily indicate future interest rate increases.
opencoder:1.5b:
The steady job growth continues in the US created fewer jobs than expected in December, but analysts said that the dip in hiring was not enough to derail the world's biggest economy.

According to Labor Department figures, 157,000 new jobs were added last month and it took 2.2 million, the best showing in five years. Job creation was one of last year's main concerns for the US economy as worries still remain, conditions are set for steady growth in 2005, analysts said.

The unemployment rate stayed at 5.4% in December, and about 200,000 jobs will need to be created each month if that figure is to drop. "It was a respectable report," said Michael Moran, analyst at Daiwa Securities. "Payroll growth in December was a little lighter than the consensus forecast, but we had upward revisions to the prior two months and an increase in manufacturing employment." That means that the Federal Reserve's policy of raising interest rates has likely been enacted.

The Fed lifted borrowing costs five times last year to 2.25%, citing evidence the US economic recovery was becoming more robust. Last year saw a slight dip but continued steady growth despite increased manufacturing employment, showcasing positive news for the economy.
smollm:1.7b:
The summary should preserve key ideas and details:

1. The US created fewer jobs than expected in December.
2. According to Labor Department figures, 157,000 new jobs were added last month. That took 2004's total to 2.2 million, the best showing in five years. Job creation was one of last year's main concerns for the US economy. While worries still remain, the conditions are set for steady growth in 2005. The unemployment rate stayed at 5.4% in December, and about 200,000 jobs will need to be created each month if that figure is to drop.
3. Payroll growth in December was a little lighter than the consensus forecast, but we had upward revisions to the prior two months and an increase in manufacturing employment. Manufacturing is a cyclical area of the economy and if it's showing job growth, it's a good indication that the economy is on a solid growth track. That means that the Federal Reserve is likely to continue its policy of raising interest rates. The Fed lifted borrowing costs five times last year to 2.25%, citing evidence the US economic recovery was becoming more robust.
4. Job creation was one of last year's main concerns for the US economy, and proved to be a main topic of debate in the US presidential election. While demand for workers is far from booming, the conditions are set for steady growth. "Overall, compared to the previous year it looks great, it just keeps going stronger and stronger and I expect that to be the case" in 2005, said Kurt Karl, economist at Swiss Re in New York. Meanwhile, economists cautioned against reading too much into data from the Federal Reserve showing an unexpected $8.7bn drop in consumer debt in November. A fall in consumer spending, which makes up about two-thirds of all US economic activity, could help limit the extent of any future interest rate rises. But economists said there could be a number of reasons for a fall in the borrowing, which includes credit cards and personal loans, while noting that such figures can vary on a month-to-month basis.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, so I need to summarize this text about job growth and the economy. The user provided an example where they converted the entire paragraph into a concise summary. Let me start by reading through the original text carefully.

The first sentence is about steady job growth in the US. Then it mentions that despite a decline in hiring, the economy was still strong because of 157,000 new jobs added last month, bringing total jobs to 2.2 million, which is better than five years ago. The unemployment rate stayed at 5.4%, and they mentioned about 200k jobs needed each month if growth continues.

There are quotes from analysts: Moran at Daiwa Securities, who talked about payroll growth being a bit lighter but with upward revisions for the past two months and higher manufacturing employment. They noted that manufacturing is cyclical, so positive growth indicates stable growth. Another quote mentions Federal Reserve raising interest rates because they helped stimulate the economy.

They also mentioned that job creation was key to the economy's success last year, especially in the election season, but some data might overstate things. Also, there were concerns about rising consumer debt and economic fluctuations.

So, putting it all together, I need to create a summary that includes the main points: steady growth, positive jobs, 157k new jobs, unemployment at 5.4%, expected job creation next year, Federal Reserve's interest rate hike, and other economic indicators like credit card spending and consumer debt.

I should make sure not to include any explanations or formatting. Just a plain text summary with key ideas preserved.
</think>

The US experienced steady job growth, adding over 157,000 jobs last month, reaching a total of 2.2 million, which is a notable increase compared to five years ago. Unemployment remained at 5.4%, and the unemployment rate continued to rise in December, with analysts warning about potential oversights in data regarding consumer debt growth. The Federal Reserve plans to raise interest rates due to economic recovery, citing robust economic activity as evidence.
tinyllama:1.1b:
Pour récapituler l'article:

L'activité économique américaine continue à baisser en 2004, mais un réchauffement en termes de création de travail est suffisant pour souligner le meilleur des deux ans. Le nombre de nouveaux emplois créés s'est inférieur à l'objectif prévoyé, mais les chiffres montrent une tendance à une baisse respectable et un niveau resté relativement stabilisé du précédent année. La croissance du marché des services n'a pas été suffisamment forte pour empêcher la fin de l'investissement d'une part, ce qui est le cas. Le niveau de l'emploi s'est rétrécit à 2,2 million d'employés, la plus baisse en cinq ans. La situation économique reste satisfaisante pour l'économie américaine, car les conditions ne se trouvent pas dans une situation de retardement de croissance. La montée du prix des produits de consommation a été le point dominant de l'année économique 2004, mais une forte baisse des débottés d'épargne a permis de préserver les conditions de croissance. Les analystes considèrent que cette baisse d'une partie du débit est réconciliable avec le niveau général de croissance du marché des services, lesquels ont suivi une bonne année 2003, et les conditions de la finance étant favorables pour l'avenir.
tinydolphin:1.1b: In summary, job creation in the US has been less than anticipated, with December's figures showing fewer new jobs than expected at 157,000. However, analysts are predicting steady growth for 2005 and expectations of continued hiring, despite the dip in employment during the year. The unemployment rate has remained at 5.4%, with an estimated need of about 200,000 jobs to be created per month if that figure is to decrease. Although payroll growth in December was respectable, analysts pointed out that this could be a result of upward revisions and increased manufacturing employment as well. The Federal Reserve's decision on interest rates remains uncertain amidst the economic recovery and concerns about potential job losses. Overall, it appears that the US economy continues to grow at a steady pace, with job creation expected to play a central role in maintaining momentum for 2005.
phi:2.7b: The US created fewer jobs than expected in December but analysts say it's not enough to derail the world's largest economy. The Labor Department reported 157,000 new jobs were added last month, taking total job creation for 2004 to 2.2 million. Job creation is one of the main concerns for the US economy and steady growth is expected in 2005. While some concerns remain, conditions are set for steady growth. Manufacturing employment, which is a cyclical sector of the economy, shows positive signs as it's showing job growth indicating that the economy is on a solid track. The Federal Reserve is likely to continue its policy of raising interest rates. Job creation was one of last year's main concerns in the US presidential election and economists say overall, the economy looks great for 2005. However, economists caution against reading too much into data from the Federal Reserve showing an unexpected drop in consumer debt in November.
orca-mini:3b: The US economy created fewer jobs than expected in December but analysts say that the dip in hiring is not enough to derail the economy. Job creation remains steady, with 157,000 new jobs added last month and upward revisions to prior months. Manufacturing employment showed job growth, indicating a solid growth track. The Federal Reserve may continue its policy of raising interest rates due to job creation being one of last year's main concerns. However, economists caution against reading too much into consumer debt figures, noting that spending could limit the extent of any future interest rate rises.
hermes3:3b: US job creation increases; 157k new positions added in Dec, continuing 2.2m jobs created in 2004. Steady growth expected for 2005 despite unemployment rate (5.4%) remaining the same. Federal Reserve likely to continue raising interest rates due to robust economic recovery signs.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Steady job growth continued in the US with 157,000 new jobs added in December, bringing the total to 2.2 million, the best showing in five years. Analysts believe the dip in hiring was not enough to halt the US economy. The unemployment rate remained at 5.4%. Although job creation stayed positive, experts warned against reading too much into data showing an unexpected $8.7bn drop in consumer debt in November. They suggested that a fall in consumer spending could limit future interest rate rises.
chatgpt-4o-latest: The US added 157,000 jobs in December, bringing the 2004 total to 2.2 million, the highest in five years. While job creation was a major concern, analysts believe conditions are set for steady growth in 2005. The unemployment rate remained at 5.4%, with 200,000 jobs needed monthly to lower it. Despite slightly lower-than-expected job growth, upward revisions for previous months and manufacturing job gains indicate economic strength. The Federal Reserve is expected to continue raising interest rates after five hikes in 2004. Economists also noted a drop in consumer debt but cautioned against overinterpreting the data, as consumer spending remains a key economic driver.
stablelm2:1.6b: The United States saw steady job growth despite a slight dip in hiring in December, with 2.2 million new jobs added, the highest number in five years. Analysts believe this indicates solid economic growth for the future. While unemployment remains high at 5.4%, analysts expect continued growth. The Federal Reserve is likely to continue raising interest rates due to evidence of a robust US economic recovery. Job creation was one of last year's main concerns for the US economy, but demand for workers is not booming. The conditions are set for steady growth, with some economists cautioning against reading too much into data from the Federal Reserve showing an unexpected drop in consumer debt.
granite3.1-dense:2b: In December 2004, the US created 157,000 new jobs, bringing the total to 2.2 million for the year—the best job growth in five years. The unemployment rate remained at 5.4%. Analysts believe this steady job creation supports a robust economic expansion in 2005, with about 200,000 jobs needed monthly to further reduce unemployment. Payroll growth was slightly lighter than anticipated but showed upward revisions for the previous two months and increased manufacturing employment, indicating a solid economic foundation. The Federal Reserve is expected to maintain its interest rate hikes, currently at 2.25%, due to this positive trend. However, economists cautioned against overinterpreting a $8.7 billion decrease in consumer debt in November, as it could potentially limit future interest rate increases. They noted that such declines can fluctuate month-to-month and may have various causes.
reference: Job creation was one of last year's main concerns for the US economy.Job creation was one of last year's main concerns for the US economy, and proved to be a main topic of debate in the US presidential election.The US created fewer jobs than expected in December, but analysts said that the dip in hiring was not enough to derail the world's biggest economy."Manufacturing is a cyclical area of the economy and if it's showing job growth, it's a good indication that the economy is on a solid growth track."While worries still remain, the conditions are set for steady growth in 2005, analysts said.The Fed lifted borrowing costs five times last year to 2.25%, citing evidence the US economic recovery was becoming more robust.The unemployment rate stayed at 5.4% in December, and about 200,000 jobs will need to be created each month if that figure is to drop.
